column2: Hannah Clarke discovered a threatening note on her estranged husbandâ€™s phone that said her children â€œwill miss you Iâ€™m sureâ€ a month before he killed them in a suburban Brisbane street, an inquest has heard. The note, discovered by Hannah Clarke on 26 January 2020, said â€œyou canâ€™t fuck with someoneâ€™s life like this and expect them to just take itâ€, the inquest was told. â€œI have told the kids that you loved them. They will miss you Iâ€™m sure,â€ counsel assisting the coroner Jacoba Brasch QC told the inquest, reading from the note found on Rowan Baxterâ€™s phone. â€œYou destroyed my life and I cannot move on. I hope all this was worth it for you and your family.â€ The comments came during the fourth day of the inquest held into the deaths of Hannah Clarke and her children â€“ Aaliyah, 6, Laianah, 4, and Trey, 3. The inquest also heard that Baxter had once dropped his estranged mother-in-law during an exercise at the gym, causing her face to split open. â€œHe laughed at me and told me to â€˜harden upâ€™, that it happens all the time if you play football,â€ his mother-in-law, Sue Clarke, told the inquest. Clarke said after he dropped her, Baxter continued laughing at her until other members at the gym pointed out that it was inappropriate. She said her daughterâ€™s estranged husband would belittle her at the gym and treated her â€œterriblyâ€. â€œHe lacked empathy with anybody,â€ she told the inquest. Hannah Clarke was taking her children to school when Baxter jumped inside the car holding a jerry can and knife. He doused her and the children in petrol and set them alight in the Brisbane suburb of Camp Hill in February 2020. In the years since, Clarkeâ€™s parents, Sue and Lloyd Clarke, have worked tirelessly to bring attention to domestic abuse and coercive control. Queensland is now considering making coercive control a criminal offence. Clarke told the inquest that her daughter â€œwalked on eggshellsâ€ around Baxter and that if she did something Baxter classed as â€œmisbehavingâ€, he would not let her look after her grandchildren. â€œIf I spoke out I would get phone calls in tears,â€ she said, referring to her daughter. â€œâ€˜Please Mum, apologiseâ€™. Sheâ€™d be so distraught that Iâ€™d have to ring and apologise.â€ She told the inquest that Baxter would refer to women as â€œfat pigsâ€ and would not let his wife wear shorts or the colour pink. Clarke said her daughter spoke to her about needing to write a will for the children as she feared Baxter would kill her. Aaliyah, Hannahâ€™s eldest child, was also afraid of Baxter, the inquest heard. â€œSheâ€™d seen so much. She would stand up to her father,â€ Clarke told the inquest. â€œHe would yell at [Hannah] and storm out of the house, and [Aaliyah] would slam the door and say and â€˜donâ€™t come backâ€™. â€œShe was outspoken â€¦ and she would be in trouble for coming into adult business.â€ Clarke told the inquest that Baxter kidnapped Laianah on Boxing Day 2019 and held her for three days, causing Aaliyah to become â€œangryâ€ and scrunch her hands into â€œlittle fistsâ€. She said that after the abduction, she would have to reassure Aaliyah every morning that she wasnâ€™t going to see her father that day. â€œEven then, when she did have to go â€¦ sheâ€™d be on the footpath crying not wanting to get in the car.â€ Clarke described another occasion two weeks before he murdered the family where Baxter attempted to break her daughterâ€™s wrist when he was dropping off Trey. She said when her daughter ran out of the house and told Baxter she would call the police, he responded by calling her â€œa moleâ€. Sign up to receive an email with the top stories from Guardian Australia every morning The inquest heard when the relationship ended, Baxter would not let his estranged wife take her name off the lease and she was forced to go to the Queensland Civil and Administrative Tribunal to get them to intervene. Clarke said her daughter believed Baxter was recording her conversations, listening to her phone calls and anything she said in her car. She said Baxter once snuck into her house while her daughter was living there with the children. â€œHannah â€¦ felt, like a shiver, and he was standing there staring at her,â€ said Clarke. Clarke said she wanted people to remember her daughter as a â€œstrongâ€ woman who loved her children â€œand would do anything to save themâ€. â€œShe wasnâ€™t perfect, nobodyâ€™s perfect, but she was a beautiful soul, she really was.â€ In Australia, the crisis support service Lifeline is on 13 11 14 and the national family violence counselling service is on 1800 737 732. In the UK, Samaritans can be contacted on 116 123 and the domestic abuse helpline is 0808 2000 247. In the US, the suicide prevention lifeline is 1-800-273-8255 and the domestic violence hotline is 1-800-799-SAFE (7233). Other international helplines can be found via www.befrienders.org
column4: â€˜They will miss youâ€™: inquest hears of note found by Hannah Clarke before she and her children were killed

column2: Up to 450 refugees from Australiaâ€™s regional processing centres will be resettled in New Zealand over the next three years, after the Coalition belatedly took up a long-standing agreement struck more than nine years ago. Up to 150 refugees a year will be able to go to New Zealand, under the deal announced by Australiaâ€™s home affairs minister, Karen Andrews, and the New Zealand immigration minister, Kris Faafoi, on Thursday. The arrangement is open only to refugees in Nauru or those who are â€œtemporarily in Australia under regional processing arrangementsâ€. It is not open to those who are â€œengaged in other third country resettlement pathwaysâ€, such as the arrangement Australia has with the US. Amnesty International said there were 112 refugees on Nauru, and another 1,168 in Australia for medical treatment, who the charity said would be eligible for resettlement under the deal. The resettlement arrangement was struck more than nine years ago, under then prime minister Julia Gillard in February 2013. Labor lost office at the federal election later that year, and the deal was not taken up by the Coalition until now. The Coalition repeatedly argued that accepting the deal might encourage a resumption of asylum-seekers attempting to travel by boat to Australia. In 2018 the then home affairs minister, Peter Dutton, said taking up the offer â€œwould be a pull factor at this point in timeâ€. The same year the prime minister, Scott Morrison, said the government was â€œvery concerned that that could risk this thing opening up againâ€. On Thursday, Andrews said that â€œAustraliaâ€™s strong border protection policies had not changedâ€, and the resettlement plan would not apply to people who attempted to come to Australia in future. â€œAustralia remains firm â€“ illegal maritime arrivals will not settle here permanently,â€ Andrews said in a statement on Thursday. â€œAnyone who attempts to breach our borders will be turned back or sent to Nauru.â€ Faafoi said his country was happy to take the refugees. â€œNew Zealand is very pleased that Australia has taken up the offer to resettle up to 150 refugees annually for three years,â€ he said. â€œWe are pleased to be able to provide resettlement outcomes for refugees who would otherwise have continued to face uncertain futures.â€ The Australian Greensâ€™ immigration spokesman, Nick McKim, said the deal was â€œa blessed, belated reliefâ€, but said it took far too long for the Australian government to accept New Zealandâ€™s offer. â€œThe last decade of offshore detention has been a dark and bloody chapter in our countryâ€™s story, and its bipartisan foundation remains a national shame,â€ McKim said in a statement.â€œWe know that the people of New Zealand will open their arms to all those who are resettled there, and give them the welcome they should have had in Australia years ago.â€ Amnesty International Australiaâ€™s refugee adviser, Graham Thom, said the belated acceptance of the deal meant that â€œpeople have had years of their lives taken from them pointlesslyâ€. â€œSadly the 104 people still trapped [in Papua New Guinea] fall outside the scope of this deal and solutions will still need to be found for them,â€ Thom said. The prominent refugee advocate Craig Foster said the announcement was a â€œsmall step to recovering Australiaâ€™s humanity and there is much work aheadâ€. â€œI thank everyone raising their voice around Australia for a commitment to basic decency, our high profile ambassadors, Jacinda Ardern, and say well done to Scott Morrison on finally taking the right action,â€ Foster said. â€œItâ€™s just the start, Scott, there are many more steps required to dismantle this beastly system.â€ Sign up to receive an email with the top stories from Guardian Australia every morning The UN High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) had long been calling on the Australian government to take up the offer. The UNHCR regional representative for Australia, New Zealand and the Pacific, Adrian Edwards, welcomed Thursdayâ€™s announcement, but said: â€œFor the refugees and asylum seekers, the prolonged uncertainty of their situation has taken an enormous toll.â€ Edwards said the UNHCR was not a party to the arrangement, but because of the â€œcompelling humanitarian circumstancesâ€ had indicated its in-principle readiness to facilitate the process of resettlement referrals to New Zealand.
column4: Australia agrees 450 refugees can be resettled in New Zealand, nine years after deal first offered

column2: Rishi Sunakâ€™s attempt to cast himself as a tax-cutting chancellor despite Britain facing the biggest drop in living standards since the 1950s is met with scorn on the front of many of Thursdayâ€™s papers. The normally pro-government Express has a surprisingly punchy splash headline saying â€œThe forgotten millions say: what about us?â€ as it reports that millions of Britons have been â€œleft without a helping handâ€ by Sunakâ€™s mini-budget. Tomorrow's front page: The forgotten millions say: what about us?#TomorrowsPapersTodayhttps://t.co/5ZawhUbkfx pic.twitter.com/J0pOJySldk The Guardianâ€™s lead is â€œCost of living surges: and Sunak squeezes poorestâ€, saying that better-off workers will benefit most from the chancellorâ€™s cut in petrol duty while ignoring the case for help to cut energy bills to help poorer households. Guardian front page, Thursday March 2022: Cost of living surges: and Sunak squeezes poorest pic.twitter.com/5rzBzIOeg3 The Telegraphâ€™s front page states the situation very bluntly with the analysis of the Office for Budget Responsibility â€“ â€œâ€˜The biggest fall in living standards on recordâ€™â€ â€“ and reports on the unease of many Tory MPs at Sunakâ€™s failure to take their advice and scrap the national insurance increases. ğŸ—ï¸The front page of tomorrow's Daily Telegraph:''The biggest fall in living standards on record''#TomorrowsPapersTodaySign up for the Front Page newsletterhttps://t.co/x8AV4Oomry pic.twitter.com/CLtOWYDERI One of the paperâ€™s columnists, Allister Heath, says Sunak has made the wrong choice by going ahead with national insurance increases and says failing to tackle the cost of living crisis â€œwill be catastrophic, appalling, and could destroy the Conservative party and its reputation for economic competence for a generationâ€. The Mail has a different spin on the Tory reaction and has the headline â€œNow slash taxes even furtherâ€, claiming that Tory MPs want more tax cuts to ease the pain on households. Thursday's @DailyMailUK #MailFrontPages pic.twitter.com/EWAj2wtdk6 The FT makes more of the fact that by proceeding with the NI rise in the face of backbench opposition, Sunak is trying to give himself room to cut income taxes before the next general election. â€œSunak banks windfall for pre-election tax cut as cost of living crisis hits homeâ€ its splash says. Tomorrowâ€™s @FT front page. Always good to pick up a paper copy the day after a big fiscal event - loads of great detail, insight and comment https://t.co/1ZGFvqvO3x The Mirror goes with â€œThanks for nothingâ€, saying on its front page that there was â€œnothing for energy bills, nothing for pensioners, and nothing to stop worst fall in living standards since the 50sâ€. Tomorrow's front page: Thanks for nothing https://t.co/Zo4XeYtZTi #TomorrowsPapersToday pic.twitter.com/CkEyBreuk8 Inside it lists 13 cost of living blows that Sunak has not addressed, from energy bills to mortgage rates. The Times has a similar headline with â€œBiggest fall in living standards since 1950sâ€, while the i says much the same: â€œBiggest hit to living standards since age of rationingâ€. Thursdayâ€™s Times: â€œBiggest fall in living standards since 1950sâ€ #BBCPapers #TomorrowsPapersToday https://t.co/xKIP4VfPYs pic.twitter.com/YOcbD7wenu The Metro says â€œNo heat to eatâ€, and reaches even further back into history to report that the tax burden is now the highest itâ€™s been since the 1940s. Thursday's front page:NO HEATTO EAT#tomorrowspaperstoday #BBCPapers #skypapers pic.twitter.com/LComva6crB The reaction of regional titles is much more pointed with the Northern Echo asking â€œIs that it?â€ despite its call for more action to ease the cost of living crisis. â€œSunak told he must do more for millions facing povertyâ€ says the Yorkshire Post. Thursdayâ€™s NORTHERN Echo: â€œ â€˜Is That It?â€™ â€œ. #TomorrowsPapersToday pic.twitter.com/VKJnREs6tS The Herald in Scotland has a more upbeat line however, reporting â€œSunak pledges tax break to two million Scots workersâ€. Thursday's HeraldTwo million Scots will keep more of their wages before having to pay National Insurance as a result of the Chancellorâ€™s Spring Statement.#TomorrowsPapersToday#scotpapers#BuyAPaper & subscribe: https://t.co/Ms01UHC8R6 pic.twitter.com/iKgb41N93Q
column4: â€˜The forgotten millionsâ€™: how the papers covered Rishi Sunakâ€™s spring statement

column2: A Manhattan prosecutor who investigated Donald Trumpâ€™s financial dealings wrote in a resignation letter that he believed Trump â€œis guilty of numerous felony violationsâ€ and blasted the new district attorney for not moving ahead with an indictment, the New York Times reported. Mark Pomerantz and Carey Dunne, two top prosecutors on the Manhattan district attorneyâ€™s criminal investigation of Trump, resigned abruptly last month, amid reports that the investigation into the former presidentâ€™s finances was foundering. The newly elected district attorney, Alvin Bragg, was reportedly more skeptical than his predecessor that the evidence his officeâ€™s attorneys had gathered against Trump would be enough to convict him. In a February resignation letter obtained by the New York Times, Pomerantz wrote that the team of lawyers investigating Trump had â€œno doubtâ€ he had â€œcommitted crimesâ€ and that Braggâ€™s decision not to move ahead with prosecuting Trump â€œwill doom any future prospects that Mr Trump will be prosecuted for the criminal conduct we have been investigatingâ€. â€œHis financial statements were false, and he has a long history of fabricating information relating to his personal finances and lying about his assets to banks, the national media, counterparties, and many others, including the American people,â€ Pomerantz reportedly wrote. The clock is ticking on the case against Trump, as the current term of the grand jury which has been hearing evidence expires in April. Ronald Fischetti, an attorney for Trump, told the Guardian that the resignation letter simply reflected the prosecuting teamâ€™s failure to make a convincing legal case against the former president, describing his clientâ€™s â€œinnocenceâ€. â€œPomerantz had several occasions to meet with Alvin Bragg, the district attorney, and his senior staff to lay out exactly what he intended to present to the grand jury in order to get an indictment, and he failed,â€ Fischetti said. â€œHe was unable to convince the DA and his senior staff that he had sufficient evidence to warrant an indictment.â€ â€œMr Bragg should be commended for not doing this on the basis of politics, and just doing it on the basis of law, which heâ€™s supposed to do,â€ Fischetti said. While the resignation letter conceded that the case against Trump could be challenging and that there were â€œrisksâ€ of bringing it to court, it argued that there was a strong public interest in prosecuting Trump â€œeven if a conviction is not certainâ€. The former Manhattan district attorney Cy Vance, who had been deeply involved in the case, had â€œdirected the team to present evidence to a grand jury and to seek an indictment of Mr Trump and other defendants as soon as reasonably possibleâ€, Pomerantz reportedly wrote, but Bragg, who was sworn in this January, reviewed the case and did not agree. Pomerantz believed Braggâ€™s decision not to seek an indictment of Trump was â€œmade in good faithâ€ but also â€œmisguided and completely contrary to the public interestâ€. Pomerantz did not respond to a request for comment. â€œThe investigation continues,â€ Danielle Filson, a spokesperson for the district attorney, wrote in an email. â€œA team of experienced prosecutors is working every day to follow the facts and the law. There is nothing we can or should say at this juncture about an ongoing investigation.â€ A spokesperson for the Trump Organization called Pomerantz a â€œnever-Trumperâ€ in a statement to the New York Times.
column4: Trump committed â€˜numerousâ€™ felonies, said resigning New York prosecutor â€“ report
